text:
SANJAY LALBHAI: And everyone was
in a denial that this cannot be
there for a long time.

How can powerlooms
be allowed to grow
without any kind of regulation?

I'm sure the government will
come down heavily on them.

They cannot keep on violating
the income tax laws.
Finally, they'll have to pay.

And I was very clear that
they were there to stay,

because they were
creating many jobs.

Small scale in a democracy,
government cannot possibly come
down very heavily on them.

So even they were
violating laws,

and they were free
of the [INAUDIBLE],,

I knew that they are
not going to go away.

So I said, let me
start facing it.
So I started looking.

So I brought in a professor
from Miami, Dr. [? Moti. ?]

He was advising textile
units on strategy.
So I got him in.

I had Dr. Rao in my
research in development

as the head of Arvind's research
and development initiative.

He was not part of
this management group.
He was a research director.

So he was also looking
into the future.

So both these gentlemen
agreed with me

that the powerlooms are
not going to go away,

and we'll have to think
about a new solution

if Arvind was to survive
and not close down.

So we started
looking for products.

So Arvind was at that time
a 100% domestic company,

making women's fabric
for the ladies'

fabrics or women's blouse
pieces, and dress materials,
and things like that.

And we were into all these
domestic product categories.
We were a very premium company.

Our products were
very well known.

Our brand was very
well established.
It had a history of success.
It had excellent management.
It had very good distribution.

These products started
getting manufactured

by the powerloom at
much lower prices,

and the distribution which we
had started buying from them
rather than us.

So it was quite obvious
that we will die.

So at that point of time, I
bumped into or I accidentally

came into realizing
that denim could have

an opportunity in this country,
because my brother-in-law, who

was, again, a graduate from
Bajaj Institute of Management,

he was also trying
to figure out.

His father was in
the army, and he
wanted to be an entrepreneur.

So he thought about
making a pair of jeans.

So he came to me and said that
I want to make a pair of jeans,
I have no denim in this country.
And I can't import it.
It's too cumbersome.

There are too many
permissions to be obtained,

and we have to make
this denim in Arvind.

So then, when we
all sat down, we

realized that it's a very,
very specialized line,

and you need special set of
equipments to make denim.

Then, Dr. Roy came
up with an idea

that we can make
denim by printing
indigo on twill fabrics.

It will not be a genuine indigo,
because otherwise, the yarn

is dyed with the indigo
dye, and the weft is white.

It's a unique combination which
makes a pair of denim or pair
of of jeans.

But we completely changed the
method of manufacturing denim,

and we printed on a
simple three up, one down

gray fabric, indigo, where
we were printing saris.

We printed on that machine
with the indigo dye
on twill fabrics.

And that would bleed, and that
would give you a nice wash
down.

It will never be as good as
the genuine denim fabrics,

but we did succeed in
manufacturing our fabric

with indigo, which would
wash down and give you
a unique look.
And that worked.
